results.title: The Dame Was Loaded
results.creator_credit: Philips Interactive Media, Inc. and Brilliant Digital Entertainment
results.brief_description: A hardboiled detective, femme fatales, missing people and money. The Dame was Loaded has all the hardboiled elements of film noir and is just as cinematic.

constellations_primary.name: The narrative power of maps
constellations_primary.description: Maps are designed to communicate complex information in a clear manner to aid both navigation and wayfinding and knowledge of place.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Philips Interactive Media, Inc. and Brilliant Digital Entertainment
results.description:
A hardboiled detective, femme fatales, missing people and money. The Dame was Loaded (1995) has all the hardboiled elements of film noir and is just as cinematic.

Created using innovative Full Motion Video (FMV) technology, which was developed in-house at Beam Software, this point-and-click adventure incorporated real footage of actors that players interact with to solve the mystery. At the time when computer graphics were limited, PMV games tried to generate empathy in players by putting them in the protagonist’s point of view and presenting other characters as real people in a fully realised game world.

When it was made it was the largest multimedia production in Australia, with game developers collaborating closely with actors and film crews, who used iconic Melbourne landmarks as settings like the art-deco former police headquarters on Russell Street.
description_for_label:
A hardboiled detective, femme fatales, missing people and money. The Dame was Loaded (1995) has all the hardboiled elements of film noir and is just as cinematic.

Created using innovative Full Motion Video (FMV) technology, which was developed in-house at Beam Software, this point-and-click adventure incorporated real footage of actors that players interact with to solve the mystery. At the time when computer graphics were limited, PMV games tried to generate empathy in players by putting them in the protagonist’s point of view and presenting other characters as real people in a fully realised game world.

When it was made it was the largest multimedia production in Australia, with game developers collaborating closely with actors and film crews, who used iconic Melbourne landmarks as settings like the art-deco former police headquarters on Russell Street.

results.title: The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith, Cannes Film Festival
results.brief_description: In the late 1970s, non-Indigenous filmmakers wanting to support Indigenous Rights in Australia released films on Black Australia to mixed success. Fred Schepisi’s controversial The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978) divided audiences and demonstrated how non-Indigenous storytellers could co-opt Indigenous stories to great detriment.
results.title_for_label: The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith, Cannes Film Festival
results.description: In the late 1970s, non-Indigenous filmmakers wanting to support Indigenous Rights in Australia released films on Black Australia to mixed success. While Fred Schepisi’s controversial The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978) divided audiences and demonstrated how non-Indigenous storytellers could co-opt Indigenous stories to great detriment, Phillip Noyce’s Backroads (1977), made in close consultation with Gary Foley, was groundbreaking for tackling racism and giving First Peoples a say in how they were portrayed.
description_for_label: In the late 1970s, non-Indigenous filmmakers wanting to support Indigenous Rights in Australia released films on Black Australia to mixed success. While Fred Schepisi’s controversial The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978) divided audiences and demonstrated how non-Indigenous storytellers could co-opt Indigenous stories to great detriment, Phillip Noyce’s Backroads (1977), made in close consultation with Gary Foley, was groundbreaking for tackling racism and giving First Peoples a say in how they were portrayed.

results.title: The Blind Man of Siloam lantern slides
results.brief_description: The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them before staging performances like The Blind Man of Siloam.

constellations_primary.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
constellations_primary.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

results.description: The Salvation Army isn’t just a part of Melbourne’s social fabric – it’s also an integral part of moving-image history. The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in elaborate sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them in the department’s Bourke Street studio. The Blind Man of Siloam shows how this technique re-created ancient locations from hand-painted backgrounds. The department’s most famous show, Soldiers of the Cross, featured over 200 slides projected from multiple lanterns, as well as hymns, music, motion-picture segments and rousing narration.
description_for_label: The Salvation Army isn’t just a part of Melbourne’s social fabric – it’s also an integral part of moving-image history. The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in elaborate sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them in the department’s Bourke Street studio. The Blind Man of Siloam shows how this technique re-created ancient locations from hand-painted backgrounds. The department’s most famous show, Soldiers of the Cross, featured over 200 slides projected from multiple lanterns, as well as hymns, music, motion-picture segments and rousing narration.

results.title: Thaumatropes
results.brief_description: A thaumatrope is an optical toy that binds a disc to lengths of string. Illustrated on each side of the disc are distinct images that become one when you pull the string and the thaumatrope spins.

constellations_primary.name: There's always a lighthouse
constellations_primary.description: The thaumatrope was an early optical illusion device popular in the Victorian era and was important to the development of the moving image.

results.description: How do you cage a bird? With a thaumatrope, an optical toy that binds a disc to lengths of string. Illustrated on each side of the disc are distinct images that become one when you pull the string and the thaumatrope spins. The first known thaumatrope was invented by John Ayrton Paris in 1824, when he used it to demonstrate his theory of ‘persistence of vision’ to London’s Royal College of Physicians.
description_for_label: How do you cage a bird? With a thaumatrope, an optical toy that binds a disc to lengths of string. Illustrated on each side of the disc are distinct images that become one when you pull the string and the thaumatrope spins. The first known thaumatrope was invented by John Ayrton Paris in 1824, when he used it to demonstrate his theory of ‘persistence of vision’ to London’s Royal College of Physicians.

results.title: TERROR NULLIUS Acquisition
results.material_description: VHS case, hard drive with USB adaptor, paper ceritificate of authenticity
results.brief_description: The acquisition of time-based media artworks requires our collection team to develop a host of preservation strategies that often go unseen by visitors. These strategies include the receipt of master moving-image files and provenance documentation. Soda_Jerk’s acquisition, presented here, displays their political and humorous sense of creativity as the humble certificate of authenticity and external hard drive packaging get a playful overhaul, which reflects the subversive nature of the artwork, TERROR NULLIUS.
results.description: The acquisition of time-based media artworks requires our collection team to develop a host of preservation strategies that often go unseen by visitors. results.title: Technicolor
results.brief_description: The first star of a Technicolor feature film was Miriam Hopkins, who played the titular character in Becky Sharp (1935), the first feature to use the three-strip technique after its introduction in 1932.

constellations_primary.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

results.description:
When most people think about Technicolor, they think about The Wizard of Oz (1939). As Dorothy steps out of her dreary sepia life and into Munchkinland, she’s enveloped in glorious Technicolor. That kaleidoscope of highly saturated hues is actually produced from just three colours – red, green and blue – recorded on individual film strips and then dyed. This is the three-strip Technicolor process.

But Judy Garland wasn’t the first star of a Technicolor feature film. That triumph goes to Miriam Hopkins, who played the titular character in Becky Sharp (1935), the first feature to use the three-strip technique after its introduction in 1932. Technicolor was the most popular colouring system in Hollywood until the mid-1950s, when single-strip processes were developed.
description_for_label:
When most people think about Technicolor, they think about The Wizard of Oz (1939). As Dorothy steps out of her dreary sepia life and into Munchkinland, she’s enveloped in glorious Technicolor. That kaleidoscope of highly saturated hues is actually produced from just three colours – red, green and blue – recorded on individual film strips and then dyed. This is the three-strip Technicolor process.

But Judy Garland wasn’t the first star of a Technicolor feature film. That triumph goes to Miriam Hopkins, who played the titular character in Becky Sharp (1935), the first feature to use the three-strip technique after its introduction in 1932. Technicolor was the most popular colouring system in Hollywood until the mid-1950s, when single-strip processes were developed.
